title: Anxiety Relief
description: Examine your fears and find calm through Stoic objective analysis.

prompts.title: Fear Setting
prompts.question: What is the worst-case scenario you are currently fearing? Describe it in full detail.
prompts.guidance: Seneca suggested 'premeditatio malorum'‚Äîrehearsing the worst. By naming the fear, you strip it of its power. Once written, ask: could I survive this?

prompts.title: Dichotomy of Control
prompts.question: What parts of your current worry are strictly within your control, and what parts are not?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus taught that suffering comes from wanting to control what we cannot. List what you can influence, then release the rest.

prompts.title: The View from Above
prompts.question: Imagine looking at your situation from 10,000 feet. How significant is this worry in the grand arc of your life?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius practiced zooming out‚Äîseeing himself as a small part of history. This isn't dismissal; it's proportion.

prompts.title: Past Evidence
prompts.question: Think of a time you were deeply anxious about something. What actually happened? How did you handle it?
prompts.guidance: Your track record of surviving difficulty is 100%. Document your resilience as evidence against catastrophic thinking.

prompts.title: The Obstacle Is the Way
prompts.question: How could this source of anxiety actually become an opportunity for growth?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius wrote: 'The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.' Every obstacle carries a hidden lesson.

prompts.title: Present Moment Anchor
prompts.question: Right now, in this exact moment, are you safe? What is actually happening versus what you are imagining?
prompts.guidance: Anxiety lives in the future. Seneca reminded us: 'We suffer more in imagination than in reality.' Ground yourself in the present.

prompts.title: The Sage's Response
prompts.question: If the wisest person you know faced your exact situation, how would they respond?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics often asked how a sage would act. This mental model separates your emotional reaction from rational action.

prompts.title: Voluntary Discomfort
prompts.question: What small, uncomfortable thing could you do today to build tolerance for uncertainty?
prompts.guidance: Seneca practiced 'voluntary discomfort'‚Äîcold baths, simple meals, hard floors‚Äîto prove to himself that the feared thing was manageable.

prompts.title: Gratitude Amid Chaos
prompts.question: Even in this anxious state, what three things in your life are genuinely going well?
prompts.guidance: Gratitude and anxiety cannot occupy the mind simultaneously. Acknowledging what works shifts the balance toward clarity.

prompts.title: Evening Reflection
prompts.question: What did you do well today despite feeling anxious? What would you do differently tomorrow?
prompts.guidance: Seneca's evening review: 'What bad habit did I curb today? What virtue did I acquire?' Progress, not perfection.

title: Safe Space Visualization
description: Construct an inner sanctuary through reflective writing and guided imagery.

prompts.title: The Inner Citadel
prompts.question: Describe a place‚Äîreal or imagined‚Äîwhere you feel completely at peace. What does it look, sound, and feel like?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius called the mind an 'inner citadel'‚Äîa place no external force can breach. Build yours in vivid detail.

prompts.title: The Guardian at the Gate
prompts.question: What thought, memory, or person would you place at the entrance of your safe space to protect it?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus taught us to guard what enters the mind. Choose your guardian deliberately‚Äîit shapes everything inside.

prompts.title: Sensory Grounding
prompts.question: Close your eyes for 30 seconds. Then write: what are 5 things you can sense right now? How do they anchor you?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics valued present-moment awareness. Sensation is the fastest route out of spiraling thought and into the body.

prompts.title: The Refuge of Memory
prompts.question: Recall a moment in your life when you felt deeply safe. Who was there? What made it feel that way?
prompts.guidance: Seneca often returned to treasured memories as fuel for resilience. Your past holds blueprints for your peace.

prompts.title: Walls of Values
prompts.question: If your safe space had walls made of your core values, what would those values be? Name three and describe them.
prompts.guidance: The Stoic virtues‚Äîwisdom, courage, temperance, justice‚Äîform the strongest walls. No external storm can topple what is built on character.

prompts.title: The Sound of Stillness
prompts.question: What sounds bring you calm? Describe the soundtrack of your inner sanctuary.
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius wrote from his tent during wars, finding internal silence amid external chaos. Sound can be chosen, not just received.

prompts.title: Letting Go at the Door
prompts.question: What worry, grudge, or obligation would you leave outside the door of your safe space today?
prompts.guidance: 'Some things are in our control and others are not.' Leave what is not yours to carry at the threshold.

prompts.title: The View from Within
prompts.question: Looking outward from your inner citadel, how does the world appear? What changes when seen from safety?
prompts.guidance: Perspective shifts when we feel secure. The Stoics saw clearly not by ignoring reality, but by viewing it from stable ground.

prompts.title: A Letter from Safety
prompts.question: Write a short note from your 'safe self' to your 'anxious self'. What would the calm version of you say?
prompts.guidance: Seneca wrote letters to his friend Lucilius as acts of philosophy. Write to yourself with the same care and wisdom.

prompts.title: Carrying It With You
prompts.question: How can you carry a piece of this safe space into your day? Name one concrete practice or reminder.
prompts.guidance: The inner citadel is portable. Marcus Aurelius ruled an empire while returning to his sanctuary daily. You need only remember it exists.

title: Stress & Anxiety Prompts
description: Explore your stressors, reactions, and coping patterns with structured clarity.

prompts.title: Stress Inventory
prompts.question: List every source of stress you are currently carrying. Large and small, name them all.
prompts.guidance: Making the invisible visible is the first step. Seneca said: 'It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a great deal of it' on unnamed worries.

prompts.title: The Body's Message
prompts.question: Where in your body do you feel stress right now? Describe the physical sensation as precisely as you can.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics recognized the body-mind connection. Tension held in the jaw, chest, or stomach is information‚Äînot weakness.

prompts.title: Pattern Recognition
prompts.question: When you look back at the past month, what situations repeatedly trigger your stress? Is there a pattern?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus taught that it's not events that disturb us, but our judgments about them. Recognizing the pattern is the first judgment to change.

prompts.title: Coping Audit
prompts.question: How did you cope with stress yesterday? Was it helpful or harmful? Be honest.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics distinguished between healthy retreat and avoidance. Drinking, doom-scrolling, and overworking are anesthetics, not remedies.

prompts.title: The Minimum Viable Day
prompts.question: If you could only do three things today without guilt, what would they be?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius: 'If you seek tranquility, do less. Or more accurately, do what's essential.' Permission to simplify is not laziness.

prompts.title: Borrowed Trouble
prompts.question: How much of your current stress is about something that hasn't happened yet? Separate fact from forecast.
prompts.guidance: 'We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.' ‚ÄîSeneca. Most of what we fear never arrives.

prompts.title: Support Map
prompts.question: Who are the people you can lean on right now? Name them. When did you last reach out?
prompts.guidance: Even the most independent Stoics valued friendship. Seneca's letters to Lucilius are proof: wisdom is shared, not hoarded.

prompts.title: The 10-10-10 Test
prompts.question: Will this stressor matter in 10 minutes? 10 months? 10 years? Write your answer for each.
prompts.guidance: Temporal distance reveals true weight. What feels crushing today often becomes a footnote in the story of your life.

prompts.title: One Kind Act
prompts.question: What is one kind thing you could do for yourself today that you normally wouldn't allow?
prompts.guidance: Self-compassion is not indulgence. The Stoics cared for the body and mind because they were instruments of virtue.

prompts.title: Rewriting the Script
prompts.question: Take your biggest stressor and rewrite the narrative. What if this is happening FOR you, not TO you?
prompts.guidance: 'Choose not to be harmed‚Äîand you won't feel harmed. Don't feel harmed‚Äîand you haven't been.' ‚ÄîMarcus Aurelius.

title: Happiness & Well-Being
description: Discover what brings genuine joy, meaning, and emotional wellness.

prompts.title: Joy Archaeology
prompts.question: When was the last time you felt genuinely happy‚Äînot excited, but deeply content? Describe the moment.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics distinguished between pleasure (hedonia) and deep fulfillment (eudaimonia). What you're searching for may already be here.

prompts.title: Enough
prompts.question: In what areas of your life do you already have 'enough'? Where is wealth already present?
prompts.guidance: 'Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.' ‚ÄîEpictetus. Define your enough.

prompts.title: Flow State
prompts.question: What activity makes you lose track of time? When did you last do it?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics valued 'energeia'‚Äîbeing fully alive in action. Flow is the modern word for this ancient practice.

prompts.title: Meaning Over Pleasure
prompts.question: What gives your life meaning right now? Is it the same thing that gives you pleasure, or different?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius found meaning in duty, not comfort. Joy that lasts comes from purpose, not entertainment.

prompts.title: The Good Day
prompts.question: Describe your ideal 'good day' from morning to night. Not a fantasy‚Äîa realistic, wonderful day.
prompts.guidance: Seneca asked us to design days worth living, then live them deliberately. Not someday. This day.

prompts.title: Social Nourishment
prompts.question: Which relationships energize you? Which ones drain you? Be specific about why.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics valued the right companions. 'Associate with people who are likely to improve you.' ‚ÄîSeneca.

prompts.title: Micro-Joys
prompts.question: List five tiny moments from this week that brought you a flicker of happiness, no matter how small.
prompts.guidance: Happiness is not a destination‚Äîit's a collection of moments noticed. Train your attention toward them.

prompts.title: What Would You Miss?
prompts.question: If you left your current life for a year, what would you miss most? This reveals what you love.
prompts.guidance: The Stoic practice of negative visualization‚Äîimagining loss‚Äîparadoxically reveals what already brings us joy.

prompts.title: Permission Slip
prompts.question: What happiness are you postponing until conditions are 'right'? What if you gave yourself permission now?
prompts.guidance: 'True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future.' ‚ÄîSeneca. Begin now.

prompts.title: The Eulogy Test
prompts.question: What would you want people to say about your life? Are you living in alignment with that vision today?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius reflected on death not with morbidity, but clarity. Let the end illuminate the path.

title: Gratitude Journal
description: Cultivate appreciation through the ancient practice of counting blessings.

prompts.title: Morning Thanks
prompts.question: What is one small thing you are grateful for this morning?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius began each day acknowledging the virtues of those around him. Start small: warmth, silence, or breath.

prompts.title: The Hidden Gift
prompts.question: What difficulty from your past are you now grateful for? What did it teach you?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics saw hardship as a gift from fate‚Äîfuel for virtue. 'Fire tests gold, misfortune tests brave people.' ‚ÄîSeneca.

prompts.title: People Who Shaped You
prompts.question: Name someone who positively influenced your life. What specific quality do you admire in them?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius dedicated Book I of his Meditations entirely to gratitude for his teachers, family, and mentors.

prompts.title: The Ordinary Miracle
prompts.question: What everyday experience do you usually take for granted that is actually remarkable?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus said: 'He is a wise man who does not grieve for the things which he has not, but rejoices for those which he has.'

prompts.title: Negative Visualization
prompts.question: Imagine you lost something you value deeply. How would you feel? Now appreciate that you still have it.
prompts.guidance: The Stoic technique of 'premeditatio malorum'‚Äîimagining loss‚Äîparadoxically deepens gratitude for what remains.

prompts.title: A Letter Unsent
prompts.question: Write a short note of thanks to someone who may never know how much they helped you.
prompts.guidance: Gratitude expressed, even privately, rewires the mind toward abundance. The act of articulating thanks is itself the benefit.

prompts.title: Body Gratitude
prompts.question: What is one thing your body did for you today that you didn't consciously ask it to do?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius reflected on the miracle of the body: breathing, healing, sensing‚Äîall without effort. Honor the vessel.

prompts.title: Abundance Audit
prompts.question: List ten things you own that someone, somewhere in the world, is praying for right now.
prompts.guidance: 'Do not indulge in dreams of having what you have not, but reckon up the chief of the blessings you do possess.' ‚ÄîMarcus Aurelius.

prompts.title: Today's Gift
prompts.question: If today were given to you as a surprise bonus day, how would you spend it differently?
prompts.guidance: Seneca urged us to treat each day as a gift: 'Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.'

prompts.title: Season of Life
prompts.question: What is one thing about this specific season of your life that will not last forever?
prompts.guidance: Impermanence is not cause for grief‚Äîit's the source of value. Appreciate what is fleeting while it is here.

title: Relationships
description: Strengthen connections through reflection on love, conflict, and support.

prompts.title: The Mirror
prompts.question: What quality in someone close to you frustrates you most? Could it be reflecting something in yourself?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius: 'Whenever you are about to find fault with someone, ask yourself: What fault of mine most nearly resembles the one I am about to criticize?'

prompts.title: Unspoken Words
prompts.question: What have you been wanting to say to someone important in your life but haven't? Why?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics valued honest speech‚Äîparrhesia. Withholding truth harms both parties. Write what needs to be said, even if only here.

prompts.title: The Inner Circle
prompts.question: Who are the five people you spend the most time with? How do they influence your character?
prompts.guidance: 'Associate with people who are likely to improve you. Welcome those who you yourself can improve.' ‚ÄîSeneca. Choose your circle with care.

prompts.title: Conflict Autopsy
prompts.question: Think of a recent disagreement. What was the other person's perspective? Can you steelman their position?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus taught that no one does wrong willingly‚Äîthey follow their best understanding. Understanding precedes resolution.

prompts.title: Love Without Attachment
prompts.question: How can you love someone deeply while accepting that you cannot control their choices or fate?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics loved fully but held loosely. Epictetus: 'Never say of anything I have lost it, only I have returned it.'

prompts.title: The Debt of Kindness
prompts.question: Who has shown you unexpected kindness recently? How did it affect you? Have you acknowledged it?
prompts.guidance: Seneca wrote an entire treatise on benefits (De Beneficiis). Recognizing kindness strengthens the social fabric.

prompts.title: Boundaries as Care
prompts.question: Where do you need to set a boundary in a relationship? How is setting that boundary an act of love?
prompts.guidance: Boundaries are not walls‚Äîthey are architecture. The Stoics maintained dignity in all relationships through clear, fair limits.

prompts.title: Forgiveness Practice
prompts.question: Is there someone you are holding resentment toward? What would it take to release it‚Äîfor your own peace?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius: 'How much more grievous are the consequences of anger than the causes of it.' Forgiveness is self-liberation.

prompts.title: The Listener
prompts.question: When was the last time you listened to someone without planning your response? What did you learn?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus: 'We have two ears and one mouth so that we can listen twice as much as we speak.' Presence is the highest gift.

prompts.title: Legacy of Connection
prompts.question: What kind of friend, partner, or family member do you want to be remembered as? Are you living that way now?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics measured character by actions, not intentions. Your relationships are the living record of your values.

title: Self-Discovery
description: Uncover your true identity, values, and life direction through deep inquiry.

prompts.title: The Essential Self
prompts.question: If you stripped away your job title, possessions, and social roles, who are you? Describe yourself in three sentences.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics distinguished between externals (things outside our control) and our prohairesis‚Äîour true choosing self. Find yours.

prompts.title: Value Excavation
prompts.question: What are the three values you would never compromise, even under pressure? When were they last tested?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus: 'First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.' Values precede action.

prompts.title: The Unlived Life
prompts.question: What path did you not take that part of you still wonders about? What does that curiosity tell you?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius reflected on choices without regret. The unlived life is a mirror‚Äîit shows what you desire, not what you lack.

prompts.title: Childhood Echoes
prompts.question: What did you love doing as a child before the world told you what to value? Is any of that still alive in you?
prompts.guidance: Before social conditioning, there was natural inclination. The Stoics called it your 'daimon'‚Äîyour inner guiding spirit.

prompts.title: The Mask Inventory
prompts.question: What masks do you wear in different parts of your life? Which one feels closest to the real you?
prompts.guidance: Seneca warned against living someone else's life. Authenticity is not rebellion‚Äîit's the alignment of inner truth and outer action.

prompts.title: Strengths and Shadows
prompts.question: What is your greatest strength? Now describe its shadow side‚Äîhow does it sometimes work against you?
prompts.guidance: Every virtue, taken to excess, becomes a vice. The Stoic path is the middle way: courage without recklessness, wisdom without paralysis.

prompts.title: The Question You're Avoiding
prompts.question: What question about your life are you afraid to answer honestly? Write it here. Then answer it.
prompts.guidance: 'We suffer not from the events in our lives, but from our judgment about them.' Face the question. The answer has been waiting.

prompts.title: Influences Audit
prompts.question: Whose opinions shape your decisions most? Are those the voices you want guiding your life?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus asked: 'Is it your concern what anyone else thinks?' Choose your influences as carefully as your diet.

prompts.title: The Future Self
prompts.question: Describe the person you want to be in five years. What daily actions bridge the gap between now and then?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics believed character is built daily, not discovered. Your future self is the sum of today's small choices.

prompts.title: What's Your Enough?
prompts.question: If you achieved everything you're currently striving for, would you be satisfied? What would you want next?
prompts.guidance: 'It is not the man who has too little that is poor, but the one who hankers after more.' ‚ÄîSeneca. Know your ending point.

title: Therapy Preparation
description: Prepare for and reflect on therapy sessions with structured journaling.

prompts.title: Session Preview
prompts.question: What is the most important thing you want to discuss in your next therapy session? Why does it matter right now?
prompts.guidance: Seneca prepared for every conversation with intention. Therapy is too valuable for improvisation‚Äîarrive with clarity.

prompts.title: Emotional Weather Report
prompts.question: Describe your emotional state this week using a weather metaphor. What's the forecast and what caused the current climate?
prompts.guidance: Naming emotions with precision reduces their grip. The Stoics catalogued their impressions (phantasiai) before responding to them.

prompts.title: Session Reflection
prompts.question: After your last therapy session, what insight stayed with you? What, if anything, did you resist hearing?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus valued the student who questioned the teacher‚Äînot from pride, but from genuine pursuit of truth. Reflect honestly.

prompts.title: Progress Check
prompts.question: What has improved since you started therapy? Be specific‚Äîeven small changes count.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics measured progress by character growth, not external results. Even the smallest shift in perception is victory.

prompts.title: The Avoided Topic
prompts.question: What topic do you consistently avoid bringing up in therapy? What makes it hard to discuss?
prompts.guidance: Seneca: 'The greatest remedy for anger is delay.' The greatest remedy for avoidance is gentle naming. Write it here first.

prompts.title: Trigger Map
prompts.question: What situations or interactions triggered strong emotional reactions this week? Describe the trigger, the emotion, and your response.
prompts.guidance: 'Between stimulus and response there is a space.' Map your triggers to widen that space for future encounters.

prompts.title: Homework Check-In
prompts.question: Did you follow through on any homework or practices from your last session? What got in the way if not?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus: 'No great thing is created suddenly.' Therapy works between sessions, not just during them. Account for the work.

prompts.title: Relationship with Therapist
prompts.question: How do you feel in the therapeutic relationship itself? Is there anything you wish were different about the dynamic?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics valued the teacher-student relationship deeply. Honest feedback strengthens the alliance.

prompts.title: Core Belief Excavation
prompts.question: What is a belief about yourself that keeps showing up in therapy? Where did it originate? Is it still true?
prompts.guidance: Many beliefs are inherited, not chosen. The Stoic practice of 'assent'‚Äîchoosing what to believe‚Äîapplies to self-narrative too.

prompts.title: Letter to Past Self
prompts.question: Write a brief letter to the version of you who first walked into therapy. What would you tell them?
prompts.guidance: Looking back with compassion is itself therapeutic. The Stoics honored the journey: every step, including the first, required courage.

title: CBT Thought Dumps
description: Unpack and restructure unhelpful thinking patterns using cognitive tools.

prompts.title: Thought Record
prompts.question: What negative thought kept repeating today? Write it down exactly as it appeared in your mind.
prompts.guidance: Epictetus: 'It is not things that disturb us, but our judgments about things.' The first step is catching the judgment.

prompts.title: Evidence For and Against
prompts.question: Take that recurring negative thought. What evidence supports it? What evidence contradicts it?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics practiced rational examination of impressions (phantasiai). Test every thought like a philosopher tests a proposition.

prompts.title: Cognitive Distortion Spotter
prompts.question: Look at your thought. Is it catastrophizing, mind-reading, black-and-white thinking, or something else? Name the pattern.
prompts.guidance: Naming the distortion is half the battle. Marcus Aurelius: 'Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact.' Especially our own opinions.

prompts.title: The Balanced Alternative
prompts.question: Rewrite your negative thought into a more balanced, realistic version. Not positive‚Äîrealistic.
prompts.guidance: The Stoic goal is not optimism but accuracy. What is the fair, honest assessment of the situation?

prompts.title: Behavioral Experiment
prompts.question: What could you do today to test whether your negative belief is actually true? Design a small experiment.
prompts.guidance: Epictetus turned philosophy into practice. Don't just think differently‚Äîact differently and observe the result.

prompts.title: Downward Arrow
prompts.question: Take your negative thought and ask 'What would that mean?' Keep asking until you reach the core fear. What is it?
prompts.guidance: Beneath surface worries lie deeper beliefs. The Stoics pursued root causes: 'Dig within. Within is the wellspring of good.' ‚ÄîMarcus Aurelius.

prompts.title: Hot Thought Analysis
prompts.question: What was the 'hottest' emotional moment of your day? What thought triggered the emotion? Rate its intensity 1-10.
prompts.guidance: Intensity is information. High heat means the thought is hitting a deep belief. Examine it with curiosity, not judgment.

prompts.title: The Friend Test
prompts.question: If your best friend had this same thought about themselves, what would you say to them?
prompts.guidance: We are often kinder to others than to ourselves. Apply the same wisdom inward. Seneca: 'Be harsh with yourself at times.'

prompts.title: Should Statements
prompts.question: Write down three 'I should' statements you carry. Now rewrite each as 'I would prefer to' or 'I choose to.'
prompts.guidance: 'Should' creates tyranny. The Stoics spoke of preferred indifferents‚Äîthings worth pursuing without being enslaved by them.

prompts.title: Weekly Pattern Review
prompts.question: Look at your week. What thought pattern kept recurring? Is it an old story or something new?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius reviewed each day. Weekly review reveals patterns invisible in the moment. Name them to tame them.

title: Dream & Nightmare Journal
description: Process dream content and uncover emotional patterns from your subconscious.

prompts.title: Dream Recall
prompts.question: Describe your most recent dream in as much detail as possible. What happened? Where were you?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics believed dreams could reveal inner states. Capture the details quickly‚Äîdreams fade within minutes of waking.

prompts.title: Emotional Residue
prompts.question: What emotion did you wake up with this morning? Can you trace it to something in your dream?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius noted how morning emotions shape the day. The feeling a dream leaves behind is often more important than its content.

prompts.title: Recurring Themes
prompts.question: Have you noticed any recurring elements in your dreams lately‚Äîplaces, people, scenarios? What might they represent?
prompts.guidance: Repetition is the subconscious knocking. The Stoics valued self-examination: what returns in dreams wants conscious attention.

prompts.title: The Nightmare Mirror
prompts.question: Describe a recent nightmare or disturbing dream. What fear or anxiety might it be reflecting from your waking life?
prompts.guidance: Nightmares are not enemies‚Äîthey are messengers from a deeper part of you. Seneca faced his fears in waking life; face yours here.

prompts.title: Dream Characters
prompts.question: Who appeared in your dream? What is your relationship with them? What role did they play?
prompts.guidance: Dream figures often represent aspects of ourselves. Every character may be a mirror. Examine who showed up and why.

prompts.title: Rewrite the Ending
prompts.question: Take a dream that ended badly or abruptly. Rewrite the ending the way you would have wanted it to go.
prompts.guidance: This is active imagination‚Äîreclaiming agency even in the dreamworld. The Stoics valued mental rehearsal; this is its nocturnal cousin.

prompts.title: Symbols and Meaning
prompts.question: Pick one vivid image from a recent dream. What does it symbolize to you personally?
prompts.guidance: Universal dream dictionaries miss the point. Your symbols are personal. A door might mean escape to one person and opportunity to another.

prompts.title: Sleep Quality Check
prompts.question: How was your sleep last night? What might have affected your dream experience‚Äîstress, screens, food, thoughts?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics valued the conditions of rest. Marcus Aurelius was deliberate about his evenings. Quality of sleep shapes quality of dreams.

prompts.title: Dream vs. Reality
prompts.question: Has a dream ever influenced a decision you made in real life? Describe what happened.
prompts.guidance: The boundary between sleeping and waking mind is thinner than we think. Pay attention to what crosses over.

prompts.title: Lucid Moment
prompts.question: Have you ever realized you were dreaming while still in the dream? What did you do? If not, what would you do?
prompts.guidance: Lucidity in dreams mirrors Stoic awareness in life‚Äîstepping back from the stream of experience to observe it. Practice both.

title: Deep Work & Focus
description: Align your daily tasks with your higher purpose and essential work.

prompts.title: The Essential
prompts.question: If you could only accomplish one thing today, what would make everything else either easier or unnecessary?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius: 'Concentrate every minute on doing what's in front of you with precise and genuine seriousness.'

prompts.title: Energy Audit
prompts.question: Where did most of your energy go yesterday? Was it aligned with what matters most to you?
prompts.guidance: Seneca warned about 'busyness as laziness'‚Äîfilling time with trivial motion instead of meaningful work.

prompts.title: Memento Mori Task
prompts.question: If this were your last working day, which task would still feel worth doing?
prompts.guidance: The urgency of mortality clarifies priorities. Use it not for panic, but for precise selection of what matters.

prompts.title: Distraction Inventory
prompts.question: What pulled your focus away today? Name the top three distractions and their triggers.
prompts.guidance: Epictetus said: 'No man is free who is not master of himself.' Document patterns to build mastery over your attention.

prompts.title: Deep Work Block
prompts.question: When was your last uninterrupted block of focused work? What conditions made it possible?
prompts.guidance: Protect your peak hours as sacred. The Stoics guarded their mornings for philosophy; guard yours for your craft.

prompts.title: Saying No
prompts.question: What commitment or obligation do you need to decline or drop to protect your most important work?
prompts.guidance: 'If you seek tranquility, do less. Or more accurately, do what's essential.' ‚Äî Marcus Aurelius. Subtraction is strategy.

prompts.title: The Craftsman
prompts.question: What skill are you currently building? What deliberate practice did you do for it this week?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics valued excellence in one's craft (arete). Not fame, not results‚Äîthe quality of effort itself.

prompts.title: Tomorrow's Setup
prompts.question: What is the single most important action you can prepare tonight to make tomorrow effective?
prompts.guidance: Seneca's evening practice included preparing the mind for the next day. Remove friction the night before.

prompts.title: Process Over Outcome
prompts.question: Name a goal you're pursuing. Now describe the daily process that leads to it, independent of results.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics controlled effort, not outcomes. Fall in love with the process and results become inevitable.

prompts.title: The Ideal Day
prompts.question: Describe your ideal productive day from morning to night. How far is today from that ideal?
prompts.guidance: Not as fantasy, but as blueprint. Marcus Aurelius structured his days with intention. Design yours.

title: Emotion Explorer
description: Examine specific emotions‚Äîfear, sadness, frustration, anger‚Äîwith Stoic clarity.

prompts.title: Name the Emotion
prompts.question: What is the dominant emotion you are feeling right now? Don't use 'fine' or 'okay'‚Äîbe precise.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics had a rich vocabulary for inner states. Precision in naming emotion is precision in understanding yourself.

prompts.title: Fear Excavation
prompts.question: What are you most afraid of right now? Go deeper than the surface‚Äîwhat is the fear behind the fear?
prompts.guidance: Seneca: 'We are more often frightened than hurt; and we suffer more often in imagination than in reality.' Name the root.

prompts.title: Anger Autopsy
prompts.question: When was the last time you felt angry? What expectation was violated? Was that expectation reasonable?
prompts.guidance: Seneca's 'On Anger': anger comes from unmet expectations. Examine the expectation before blaming the world.

prompts.title: Sadness as Teacher
prompts.question: What is your sadness trying to tell you? If it could speak in full sentences, what would it say?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics didn't reject emotion‚Äîthey examined it. Sadness often points to something deeply valued. What is it pointing to?

prompts.title: Frustration Decoder
prompts.question: What situation is frustrating you most right now? Is the frustration about the situation or about your inability to change it?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus: 'Don't demand that things happen as you wish, but wish that they happen as they do, and you will go on well.'

prompts.title: Joy Inventory
prompts.question: When did you last feel pure, uncomplicated joy? Describe the moment. What was present, and what was absent?
prompts.guidance: Joy often appears when expectations are dropped. Notice what conditions create it‚Äîthen create those conditions more often.

prompts.title: Shame vs. Guilt
prompts.question: Is there something you feel ashamed of recently? Is the feeling about what you did (guilt) or who you are (shame)?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics distinguished between correctable actions and immutable identity. Guilt says: I made a mistake. Shame says: I am a mistake. Only one is true.

prompts.title: Emotional Forecast
prompts.question: Based on your current emotional state, what kind of day do you expect tomorrow to be? What could shift that forecast?
prompts.guidance: Emotions forecast behavior. The Stoics intervened at the level of impression‚Äîchange the forecast by changing the interpretation.

prompts.title: The Emotion You Avoid
prompts.question: Which emotion do you have the hardest time sitting with? Why? What happens when you try to just let it be?
prompts.guidance: Resistance magnifies suffering. Marcus Aurelius: 'Accept the things to which fate binds you.' This includes uncomfortable feelings.

prompts.title: Emotional Growth
prompts.question: Compare your emotional responses now to a year ago. Where have you grown? Where do you still struggle?
prompts.guidance: The Stoic path is measured in emotional maturity‚Äînot the absence of feeling, but the quality of response. Honor your progress.

title: Love & Partnership
description: Examine your readiness for love and what kind of partner you truly are.

prompts.title: The Partner You Are
prompts.question: Honestly describe yourself as a partner. What do you bring to a relationship? What do you withhold?
prompts.guidance: Marcus Aurelius began his Meditations by listing what he owed to others. Begin by listing what you offer‚Äîand what you guard.

prompts.title: Attachment Patterns
prompts.question: When someone gets close, do you pull them in or push them away? Describe what happens in your body and mind.
prompts.guidance: Epictetus taught awareness of automatic responses. Attachment patterns are not destiny‚Äîthey are habits. And habits can be examined.

prompts.title: The Ideal Partnership
prompts.question: Describe your ideal relationship‚Äînot the person, but the dynamic. How do you want to feel daily with a partner?
prompts.guidance: The Stoics focused on character, not appearances. Define the relationship by its quality of interaction, not by a checklist of traits.

prompts.title: Past Relationship Autopsy
prompts.question: What is the most important thing your last relationship (or dating experience) taught you about yourself?
prompts.guidance: Seneca: 'Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.' Every relationship, even the painful ones, is a teacher.

prompts.title: The Deal Breaker vs. The Preference
prompts.question: List your non-negotiables in a partner. Now separate true deal-breakers from mere preferences. Be ruthlessly honest.
prompts.guidance: The Stoics distinguished between what is essential and what is preferred. Confusing the two creates either loneliness or compromise.

prompts.title: Fear of Intimacy
prompts.question: What scares you most about being truly known by another person? What are you afraid they'll see?
prompts.guidance: Vulnerability is not weakness‚Äîit is the foundation of authentic connection. Seneca shared his deepest fears openly in his letters.

prompts.title: Love Languages Audit
prompts.question: How do you naturally express love? How do you prefer to receive it? Is there a mismatch you've noticed?
prompts.guidance: Self-knowledge is the basis of good partnership. The Stoics valued 'oikeiosis'‚Äîthe natural affinity between people. Understand your own wiring first.

prompts.title: Wholeness Before Partnership
prompts.question: What parts of your life are you hoping a partner will 'complete' or fix? Can you address any of those yourself?
prompts.guidance: Epictetus: 'No man is free who is not master of himself.' A partner should enhance a whole life, not fill an empty one.

prompts.title: The Courage to Be Chosen
prompts.question: Do you believe you deserve love? If hesitation appeared, explore it. Where does that doubt originate?
prompts.guidance: Self-worth is not arrogance‚Äîit is the recognition that you, like all beings, are worthy of connection. The Stoics saw dignity as inherent.

prompts.title: A Letter to Your Future Partner
prompts.question: Write a short letter to your future partner. What do you want them to know about who you are and what you're working on?
prompts.guidance: Seneca's letters to Lucilius were acts of love disguised as philosophy. Write to someone who doesn't exist yet‚Äîwith the honesty they deserve.
